title: Simple circuits - 3 switches to light 2 of 3 bulbs

content.question:
In the circuit shown, switches <math alttext="S sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>S</mtext><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, <math alttext="S sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>S</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math>, and <math alttext="S sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>S</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math> are used to control lightbulbs <math alttext="B sub X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>X</mtext></msub></math>, <math alttext="B sub Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>Y</mtext></msub></math>, and <math alttext="B sub Z" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>B</mtext><mtext>Z</mtext></msub></math>. Which of the following switch settings results in only two of the three bulbs lighting up?
<math alttext="S sub 1" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>S</mtext><mn>1</mn></msub></math><math alttext="S sub 2" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>S</mtext><mn>2</mn></msub></math><math alttext="S sub 3" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>S</mtext><mn>3</mn></msub></math>AOpenOpenClosedBOpenClosedClosedCClosedOpenClosedDClosedClosedOpen

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
